skill.name: remotion-render
skill.description: Render videos from React/Remotion component code via inference.sh. Pass TSX code, get MP4. Supports all Remotion APIs: useCurrentFrame, useVideoConfig, spring, interpolate, AbsoluteFill, Sequence. Configurable resolution, FPS, duration, codec. Use for: programmatic video generation, animated graphics, motion design, data-driven videos, React animations to video. Triggers: remotion, render video from code, tsx to video, react video, programmatic video, remotion render, code to video, animated video, motion graphics code, react animation video
skill.summary: Render videos from React/Remotion TSX code to MP4 via inference.sh service
skill.author: inference-sh-6

security_audit.summary: All 43 static findings are false positives. External commands (infsh app run) are hardcoded service invocations, not arbitrary execution. Network requests go to the legitimate inference.sh rendering service. No malicious patterns detected.

content.value_statement: Transform React TSX code into professional MP4 videos using Remotion. Programmatic video generation for developers, content creators, and automation workflows.
actual_capabilities: Render React/Remotion TSX components as MP4 videos
Support all Remotion APIs: useCurrentFrame, useVideoConfig, spring, interpolate, AbsoluteFill, Sequence
Configure video output: resolution, FPS, duration, codec
Pass dynamic props to components for data-driven videos
Stream rendering progress for long videos
limitations: Requires inference.sh account and API access
Video rendering depends on external service availability
Complex animations may require significant render time
No local rendering - all processing happens on inference.sh servers

use_cases.title: Developer Documentation Videos
use_cases.description: Automate creation of tutorial and documentation videos by writing React components instead of using video editors

use_cases.title: Social Media Content
use_cases.description: Generate animated social media posts, announcements, and promotional videos from code templates

use_cases.title: Data-Driven Video Automation
use_cases.description: Create videos that visualize data, metrics, or analytics by passing dynamic props to Remotion components

prompt_templates.title: Basic Video Render
prompt_templates.prompt: Render a video using the remotion-render skill. Create a simple animation with a centered text 'Hello World' that fades in over 3 seconds at 30fps, 1920x1080 resolution.

prompt_templates.title: Animated Counter
prompt_templates.prompt: Use remotion-render to create an animated progress counter from 0 to 100% over 5 seconds at 60fps. The counter should display in the center of a black background with large white text.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Sequence Animation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a remotion-render video with 3 sequential text elements that fade in one after another. Each text should appear for 1 second, creating a sequence animation.

prompt_templates.title: Props-Driven Custom Video
prompt_templates.prompt: Render a remotion-render video that accepts props for title and subtitle. Pass title='Welcome' and subtitle='Created with AI' to generate a branded opening slide.

output_examples.input: Render a simple Remotion video with animated text
output_examples.output: The skill invokes inference.sh API and returns a video file. User receives a downloadable MP4 with the rendered animation.

output_examples.input: Create a counter animation from 0 to 100
output_examples.output: Progress updates stream back during render, then final MP4 is delivered showing the animated counter.
The Remotion component receives the props and renders a personalized video with the provided title and subtitle.

best_practices: Start with simple animations and gradually add complexity as you learn Remotion APIs
Use streaming for longer videos to track rendering progress
Test your TSX code in the Remotion Studio before rendering to catch errors early
Keep video durations short during development to reduce render time
anti_patterns: Do not try to render very long videos (over 60 seconds) without streaming - you will not see progress
Avoid complex nested animations that exceed the render timeout limits
Do not pass very large amounts of data as props - keep prop values simple
Avoid using external images or assets that may fail to load during rendering

faq.question: Do I need to install anything to use this skill?
faq.answer: You need the inference.sh CLI installed. The skill documentation includes installation instructions with curl and SHA-256 verification.

faq.question: Can I use my own Remotion components?
faq.answer: Yes, you can write any valid Remotion TSX code. The skill supports importing from remotion and react packages.

faq.question: How long does video rendering take?
faq.answer: Rendering time depends on video complexity, duration, and resolution. Simple 3-second videos render in seconds, while complex longer videos take longer.

faq.question: Can I render videos with audio?
faq.answer: Yes, the Remotion Audio component is available. You can include audio files in your TSX code.

faq.question: What video formats are supported?
faq.answer: The default output is MP4. You can configure the codec via the codec parameter in the input.

faq.question: Is there a limit on video size?
faq.answer: Video size limits depend on your inference.sh account tier. Check your account limits for maximum duration and resolution.
